poem:
**Bank Holiday Breeze**

In the sunlit air, carnival's hum  
Contours of heat rise,  
Undulating the streets, London sings,  
beneath azure skies.  
Anticipation dances, vibrant as  
notebooks filling—  
Yet whispers of Erin  
in a distant pulse  
hint at the rain's insistence,  
a promise caught  
in the curve of a cloud.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "UK weather: bank holiday sun forecast for most with highs of 30C in places Bank holiday temperatures are expected to soar to near 30C (86F) across parts of the UK on Monday before the remnants of Hurricane Erin bring wind and rain. Maximum temperatures on Sunday will be about 26C or 27C, then those attending Notting Hill carnival in London on Monday can expect it to reach 28C or 29C with widespread sunshine for most,". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
